EMC General Considerations

Ground Ring

PCB ground (GND) rings on all layers with GND PTH vias are recommended along the edge of the board. Multiple mounting holes should be used connecting the PCB GND to chassis ground. It can significantly reduce the PCB edge coupled noise.

Guidelines for PCB GND Ring and GND Stitching Vias

Multiple GND stitching vias are required on all mechanical mounting pads including for internal device modules (e.g. SSD, WiFi module) and I/O connectors (e.g. USB, DP) throughout the platform.

Ground Ring with Ground Vias

Connector Decoupling

Place a decoupling capacitor (0.1 uF, 0402 or smaller) on the power pins of all internal and external connectors to reduce power noise. These connectors include HDMI, DP, eDP, USB, Type C, FPC connectors, M.2, PCIe edge connector, etc.

Decoupling Capacitors Placement on Connector Power Pins

Crossing Splits in Reference Plane

Crossing a split in the reference plane increases emissions from signal traces. Avoid crossing plane splits by moving the traces or reshape the reference plane.

Avoid Signal Traces Routings Across Split Planes

Reference Discontinuity

Changing reference plane from GND to power plane, or from power plane A to power plane B, may significantly increase noise emission. It is recommended to have stitching capacitors (0.1 uF, 0402 or smaller) to bridge the two reference planes and provide current return path and the stitching capacitor must be placed as close as possible to the signal trace.

Reduce Signal Referencing Discontinuities Impact

EMC Audio

Audio ESD Protection

Audio jack needs to have ESD protection. The ESD diodes need to connect to digital / chassis ground.

Audio Jack ESD Protection

DMIC EMI/ RFI Risk

DMIC clock may have EMI/ RFI risk due to its high-order harmonics.

It is recommended to have stripline routing and a placeholder for an RC filter before being routed in microstrip/ cable to reduce high-frequency harmonics.

The RC value may vary according to the board design to meet the electrical requirements.

Routing Requirements and RC Filter for DMIC Clock

EMC Component Selection

Common Mode Choke Selection

The common mode choke (CMC) selection is shown below.

Alternatively, PCB CMC can be also considered for DP 1.4, DP 2.0, eDP 1.4, eDP 1.5, Type-C USB+DP (10 Gbps), USB3.2 Gen 1 and USB3.2 Gen2 signal. Refer to #546122 for Intel PCB Common Mode Choke License Technology Technical White Paper.

Interface Data Rate CMC Placement CMC Cutoff Frequency (3dB Bandwidth) CMC Insertion Loss CM Rejection (10-dB Band) $[internal] Reference Part 
DP 1.4 / HBR3.0 8.1 Gb/s <25 mm routing length from connector >10 GHz <1.2 dB @ 5 GHz 1.8-3.8 GHz NFG0QHB372HS2 
DP 2.0 / UHBR 10 10 Gb/s <25 mm routing length from connector >10 GHz <1.2 dB @ 5 GHz 1.8-3.8 GHz NFG0QHB372HS2 
DP 2.1 / UHBR 20  20 Gb/s <25 mm routing length from connector >10 GHz <0.62 dB @ 10GHz 1.8-3.8 GHz NFG0QHB542HS2 
eDP 1.4 8.1 Gb/s <25 mm routing length from connector >10 GHz <1.2 dB @ 5 GHz 1.8-3.8 GHz NFG0QHB372HS2 
eDP 1.5 8.1 Gb/s <25 mm routing length from connector > 10 GHz < 1.2 dB @ 5 GHz 1.8 - 3.8 GHz NFG0QHB372HS2 
HDMI 2.0 (ALS topology with Post channel length <=1 Inch)* 6 Gb/s <25 mm routing length from connector > 10 GHz < 1.2 dB @ 5 GHz, <2.02 dB @3.0 GHz1.8 - 3.8 GHz DLM0NSM900HY2D 
HDMI 2.0 (ALS topology with Post channel length >>1 Inch)*  6 Gb/s <25 mm routing length from connector >6 GHz <0.80 dB @1.5 GHz, <1.50 dB @3.0 GHz 0.3-3.8 GHz DLM0QSB350HY2 
HDMI 2.1 12 Gb/s <25 mm routing length from connector >10 GHz <1.0 dB @ 6 GHz 0.3-3.8 GHz NFG0QHB372HS2 
Type-C USB+DP 10 Gb/s <25 mm routing length from connector >10 GHz <1.2 dB @ 5 GHz 1.8-3.8 GHz NFG0QHB372HS2 
USB2.0** 480 Mb/s <25 mm routing length from connector   <0.2 dB @240 MHz 0.5-2.0 GHz DLW21SN900SQ2L 
USB3.2 Gen 1 5 Gb/s <25 mm routing length from connector >7.5 GHz <1.5 dB @2.5 GHz 1.8-3.8 GHz NFG0QHB372HS2 
USB3.2 Gen 2 10 Gb/s <25 mm routing length from connector >10 GHz <1.2 dB @ 5 GHz 1.8-3.8 GHz NFG0QHB372HS2 

* Refer to SI section for next level details about HDMI 2.0 ALS topology and channel length-based CMC section.

** Common mode chokes with a target common mode impedance of 80 to 90 Ohm at 100 MHz generally provide adequate noise attenuation for USB2.0.

CMC Placement Guideline for USB3 Interface

Port Usage ScenarioCMC Guideline
USB3 onlyPlace Tx CMCs; Rx CMCs are optional
USB3 & DPPlace both Tx and Rx CMCs due to emission from DP
USB3 & TBTDo not place either Tx or Rx CMCs

ESD Diode Selection

ESD diode selection recommendations below only apply to interfaces with:

  • Hotplug input/output port application (external ports that exposed to end user)

  • Direct connection between SOC and connector (Eg, without redriver / retimer in between)

For interfaces that require retimer:

  • Intel retimer: Please refer to Thunderbolt retimer or controller documentation for more details, document number can be found in PDG chapter “EMC/RF Reference Documents”.

  • Third party retimer: Customer may contact vendor for necessary ESD protection.

For further ESD design optimization, customer may refer to Chapter “System Efficient ESD Design (SEED)” for more details.

Interface Data Rate ESD Diode Placement ESD Diode Shunt Capacitance ESD Diode Rdyn ESD Diode Reverse Working Voltage $[internal]Reference Part 
DP 2.1 HBR3 (Data) 8.1 Gbps < 25 mm routing length from connector < 0.4 pF < 0.5 Ohm 3.3 V PESD3V3Z1BSF 
DP 2.1 UHBR 10 (Data) 10 Gbps < 25 mm routing length from connector < 0.35 pF < 0.5 Ohm 3.3 V PESD3V3Z1BSF 
HDMI 2.1 Direct Connect Rate ≤ 6 Gbps (Data)   ≤ 6 Gbps < 25 mm routing length from connector < 0.4 pF < 0.5 Ohm 3.3 V PESD3V3Z1BSF 
HDMI 2.1 Direct Connect Rate > 6Gbps (Data)> 6 Gbps < 25 mm routing length from connector < 0.4 pF < 0.5 Ohm 3.3 V PESD3V3Z1BSF 
HDMI connector HPD/DDC pins   < 25 mm routing length from connector     5.0 V PESD5V0H1BSF 
Type-C USB+DP 10 Gbps < 25 mm routing length from connector < 0.35 pF < 0.5 Ohm 1.0 V ESDL2011, ESDL2012
Type-C connector CC1/CC2 pins   < 25 mm routing length from connector     5.5 V ESD131-B1-W0201  
Type-C connector SBU1/SBU2 pins   < 25 mm routing length from connector     5.5 V ESD108-B1-CSP0201 
USB2.0 480 Mbps < 25 mm routing length from connector < 1.5 pF < 0.8 Ohm 5.5 V ESD131-B1-W0201 
USB3.2 Gen1 5 Gbps < 25 mm routing length from connector < 0.5 pF < 0.5 Ohm 3.3 V ESD102-U1-02ELS  
USB3.2 Gen2 10 Gbps < 25 mm routing length from connector < 0.35 pF < 0.5 Ohm 3.3 V PESD3V3Z1BSF 

Other Component Selection

Interface/ IO Connector Component RequirementRecommended Part Number/ Part Value
AC JACKFerrite bead on power and ground pins of AC JACK BLM18SG121TN1 (up to 3 A) / BLM31SN500SH1 (up to 12 A)
DMIC22 Ω + 27 pF (Placeholder)
SPIPlaceholder for shunt capacitor (value TBD)
Type-C connector CC pinsDecoupling capacitors on CC1 and CC2 pins Refer to USB PD Specification, if not 200 pF as recommendation.
Type-C connector Tx/ Rx AC capsAC caps for Tx, Rx lanesIn order to avoid EOS damage due to shorting between VBUS and adjacent pins, AC cap with voltage rating >= 50 V is required for both Tx and Rx lanes. The AC cap needs to be next to the connector and followed by ESD diode.
Type-C connector VBUS pinsFerrite bead on VBUSOptional. Selection based on current rating requirement of the platform.
Type-C connector VBUS pinsDecoupling capacitors on VBUS signal pins (x4)0.1 uF
Voltage regulatorEMI filter at the voltage input (ferrite, diode, resistor)Refer to the tab on EMC Voltage Regulator.
XTAL circuitSeries 0 Ohm resistorsRefer to the tab on EMC XTAL RF Immunity.
Components for Type-C Interface
AC Capacitors Voltage Rating for Type-C TX and RX
Ferrite Bead for Power and Ground Pins of AC Jack

PCB CMC

Refer to #546122 for Intel PCB Common Mode Choke License Technology Technical White Paper.

PCB Common Mode Choke Design

System Efficient ESD Design (SEED)

SEED defines an ESD robustness design concept that assures matching between PCB protection components and IC IO behavior during system ESD discharges event. This design concept is applying to hotplug input/output port application, that includes USB2, USB3, Type-C, Display Port, and HDMI.

SEED Block Diagram

Refer to Intel System Efficient ESD Design (SEED) Models User Guide (# 702999) for step by step simulation using ADS* and Hspice*.

Intel® SEED Analysis Template

EMC Mechanical Consideration

Mechanical design of the system plays a critical role in meeting requirements for EMI, ESD, RFI, RF Immunity and EFT. The broad categories of consideration in mechanical design are chassis design, connector selection and grounding, high speed cable design and grounding. Refer to Intel White Paper #602554 "Chassis Design Guidelines for Improving RF Immunity and Electromagnetic Compatibility" for detailed design guidelines.

Chassis Design Considerations

It is recommended to have conductive coating used for chassis covers (in case of plastic chassis) and coating should also cover the chassis sidewalls. Refer to Intel White Paper #602554 for guidelines on the coating thickness and selection criteria.

EMI Coating on Non Metallic Chassis

Conductive contacts along the mating interface between two covers of the chassis are required to reduce the size of the openings between chassis covers. Left figure below shows the chassis contact impact between the ‘C’ and ‘D’ faces of the chassis. Mounting holes for screws that are used to secure the motherboard to the chassis or between chassis faces should not have non-conductive coating and the PCB solder mask exposed for the screw to make contact to the PCB ground. The metal back-plate of the LCD screen and back-plate of the keyboard should not be left as a floating metal, and they should be properly grounded. Refer to Intel White Paper #602554 for further guidance on the contact between chassis faces.

Conductive Contacts for Chassis Faces and PCB Ground

The metal shell of IO connectors, such as USB3, HDMI etc. should make contact to the chassis either using EMI gaskets of metal fingers in the chassis. Figure in right shows a block diagram of gasket making connection between IO connector and chassis. For the commonly used fabric-over-foam gaskets to be effective, a minimum of 20% or higher compression is required.

Gasket with Compression to Connect IO Connector and Chassis

The receptacle connector should have good area of contact to the printed circuit board. Figure below shows an example of metal fingers in chassis for IO connector contacts.

Metal Fingers in Chassis for IO Connector Contact

The thermal solution (heat pipe, cold plate) should be grounded to eliminate/reduce any resonance effects that could amplify noise in vicinity. EMI gasket material can be applied to ground the thermal solution at multiple locations (either to PCB ground or chassis ground). Grounding near the fins is also recommended. Refer to Intel White Paper #602554 for further guidance on the thermal solution grounding.

Thermal Solution Grounding

Internal Cable/Connector Routing and Shielding

Cable Routing

In a typical laptop system, several internal cables are used to connect to components such as speakers, displays, daughter cards etc. The routing of the internal cables is critical to reduce the amount of noise coupling to the sensitive circuits or nearby radio antennas, especially for the cables without good shielding. Routing cables close to the aggressor like DDR, HSIO, and SSD, could result in critical radio frequency interference (RFI) and EMI (regulatory) issues. For further guidelines on cable routing, refer to Intel White Paper #602554.

Cable and connector shielding

  • A shielded micro-coax cable assembly or 3-layer FPC cable are recommended for high-speed signals.

  • The method by which the shield layers of a cable are well contacted to ground has a significant impact on mitigating the noise radiation. A floating shield layer does not provide a return current path and may even make the noise radiation worse.

  • The shield layer(s) of the cable should make contact to the plug shell (ground) of the cable.

  • In addition, the receptacle of the cable should have ground contact to the PCB ground at multiple locations or to the chassis through the gasket.

Grounding Scheme for Internal Cable and Connector
Examples of ground contacts on the receptacle of the cable and connector

Type-C Receptacle Connector Selection

Following are the recommendations for USB Type C, A receptacle connector selection.

Connector Selection and RFI Mitigation
Avoid Holes and Slits in Type-C Receptacle Connector

Antenna Barricade Technology

Technical white paper (#636597) is available to mitigate the RFI noise using “Antenna Barricade Technology”. The purpose of the white paper is to promote antenna barricade technology and to explain how to design effective barricades using off-the-shelf Wi-Fi antennas. This technology contrasts to conventional EMI shields that are applied to motherboard platform noise sources. The design choice (antenna barricade, conventional EMI shields, or the combination of two) has to be made before chassis designs where barricade or metallic wall is formed as shown in the whitepaper. 10~15 dB RFI reduction is achieved using antenna barricade across entire Wi-Fi frequency bands up to 7.125 GHz. Barricade technique can provide several advantages over conventional on-board EMI shields:

  • Relatively easy to achieve high broadband RFI shielding effectiveness with low BOM cost.

  • No dependency on heat solutions (active, passive) or PCB technology (Type-3 or Type-4).

A legal agreement is required to use the Intel Antenna Barricade Technology. Contact Intel field representative for additional details.

Crystal RF Immunity

The crystal oscillator that provides the input clock to the CPU has been identified to be very sensitive to RF power from nearby radios. Radiated power from internal WWAN and WLAN antennas as well as from external WWAN/ WLAN devices placed near the platform can couple to the crystal and corrupt the clock signal causing issues such as screen flickering and system hang. Similarly the crystal used with the Thunderbolt retimer is very sensitive to RF power, and noise from nearby antennas can result in connection loss with the device plugged into the Thunderbolt port. Refer to retimer collaterals (document number: #572046) for XTAL specifications. The following RF Immunity Guidelines apply to both the 38.4 MHz crystal, RTC (real-time clock) crystal as well as the Thunderbolt/ retimer crystal.

  • Follow crystal routing guidelines very carefully. (Refer to XTAL design guidelines section).

  • Implement a ground ring surrounding crystal and related components. Refer to below figure. Do not connect external load caps to GND ring, but rather directly to GND plane on adjacent layer.

  • Use a shielded crystal component.

  • Ensure that external high speed IO (SATA, USB3.x/2/1.x, DP) and internal high speed IO (PCIe) traces are not routed in close proximity to the crystal components and traces (XTAL_IN/OUT).

  • Place crystal far away from antennas and potential RF power coupling paths such as unshielded/ungrounded cables. Exact distance needed depends on platform design. Platforms without board shield may have higher risk.

  • Chassis shielding and design plays a critical role in RF immunity. Refer to the EMC Mechanical Considerations section.

  • 0 Ohm resistors R1 and R2 are required as potential stuffing options. Design a common footprint for the 0 Ohm resistor (default stuffing), such that other SMT component such as a CM filter or ferrite beads can be stuffed. Potential stuffing options include a common mode choke or two ferrite beads. The common footprint should be placed as close as possible to CPU side (not XTAL side).

The following RF guideline apply to RTC (real-time) crystal

  • Design a footprint for the RF cap on the power plane (VCCRTC) for RTC. The capacitance of the stuffed RF cap should be tuned with respect to the potential unintended RF power. The footprint should be as close as possible to CPU side.

RF caps placement recommendation for RTC crystal

XTAL Ground Ring Requirements

Adding a ground ring surrounding the crystal component, related components and routing can help reduce RF immunity risk.

Guidelines for XTAL Ground Ring Implementation and Components for RF Immunity

Memory RFI Mitigation

Memory interface and DRAM devices generate narrowband and broadband RFI noise. The noise may interfere with radio bands. The following guidelines help to reduce the RFI risk due to memory.

Memory RFI Mitigation Consideration

Design AreaWi-Fi only designsWi-Fi and WWAN/ 5G designs
Memory signals on Type-4 boardFully stripline required Fully stripline required
Memory signals main routing on Type-3 boardMain routing fully stripline requiredMain routing fully stripline required
Memory signals breakout routing on Type-3 boardDQ microstrip breakout signals <= 6.5 mm CLK, WCK, DQS, CA microstrip breakout signals <= 9 mmDQ microstrip breakout signals <= 6.5 mm CLK, WCK, DQS, CA microstrip breakout signals <= 9 mm
Memory device (SODIMM, solder down memory) shieldingRequired antenna distance needs to be considered based on system dependencyRequired antenna distance needs to be considered based on system dependency
Exposed memory power planes referenced to groundRF capacitors are recommendedRF capacitors are recommended
Exposed memory power planes referenced to memory signalsOn-board shield required and RF capacitors are requiredOn-board shield required and RF capacitors are required Additional RF capacitors for WWAN interfere frequencies may require
Memory Radio Frequency Interference Mitigation (RFIM) EnablingRecommended. Please refer to Intel White Paper # 640438Recommended. Please refer to Intel White Paper # 640438

Memory Signals Design Guidelines

It is recommended that DQ/ CLK/ DQS/ WCK/ CA signals are routed in inner layers, or the microstrip breakout trace length is required to be minimized as table below. An isolation ground guard ring is recommended on the surface layer between memory power plane and memory breakout signal routing.

Signal TypesTotal Microstrip Breakout Length (mm)
DQ<= 6.5
CLK, WCK, DQS, CA<= 9

* BI microstrip length should be ≤ 1.5 mm based on system dependency.

Memory Power Plane Routing Guidelines

It is recommended to embed memory power planes in inner PCB layers. If embedding memory power plane is not possible, please consider the following design guide:

When exposed memory power planes (VDD2/VDDQ) are referenced to solid GND, and memory data rate falls into Wi-Fi 2.4 GHz/ 5 GHz/ 6 GHz and WWAN radio bands, exposed memory power planes can radiate narrowband RFI noise at data rate frequency.

  • Recommend adding platform RF capacitors to mitigate power plane noise (refer to exposed memory Power plane RF capacitors decoupling below).

  • Recommend shielding exposed memory power planes or add absorber.

  • If data rate does not fall into radio bands, the platform RF capacitors guideline can be optional.

When exposed memory power planes are referenced to memory signals, exposed memory power planes can radiate both narrowband and broadband RFI noise.

  • Require platform RF capacitors to mitigate power plane noise (refer to exposed memory power plane RF Capacitor placement as below).

  • Require shielding on exposed memory power planes or add absorber.

  • Highly recommend avoiding surface memory power plane reference to memory signal, instead, surface memory power planes shall be referenced to solid GND plane in adjacent layer.

RFI Suppression Guidelines on Memory Signal and Power Plane Exposure
Exposed Memory Power Plane RF Decoupling Capacitors

Memory power plane could be shared or separated based on design configuration.

RF decoupling capacitors are paired in groups.

  • 0402 12 pF and 0402 2.2 pF

  • 0201 15 pF and 0201 3.0 pF

RF decoupling capacitors pairs placement.

  • < 4 mm proximity from CPU and memory devices

  • Pair-to-pair distance < 12 mm.

  • Evenly distributed.

Memory Devices

Memory devices (ex. DRAM, SODIMM, LPCAMM2) can radiate broadband and narrowband RFI noise and may cause radio frequency interference. A combination of EMI shield and antenna placement is one of the solutions to mitigate noise from memory devices.

SODIMM memory devices can cause higher RFI noise than the soldered down DRAM devices and it is recommended to use an EMI shield for the SODIMM memory devices and/or use the DDR RFI Mitigation (RFIM) software feature.

Refer to the sections “On-Board Shielding” and “Intel DDR RFI Mitigation (RFIM) Software Feature” for more information.

LPCAMM2 PCB Design Guidelines

  • Avoid exposed power planes under the LPCAMM2 connector region.

It is recommended to route ground (GND) planes in the LPCAMM2 connector area on motherboard on both top and bottom layers. Avoid routing any power shapes in this region to reduce any power plane noise coupling to LPCAMM2 backplate or module. Distribute GND stitching vias across the GND plane.

Avoid Exposed Power Planes Under the LPCAMM2 Connector Region

  • LPCAMM2 backplate grounding and module retention screws

For improved RFI performance, it is recommended to ensure a ground connection between the LPCAMM2 module and the PCB.

  1. Expose ground pads with multiple ground stitching vias around mechanical mounting/screw holes on the bottom side of the motherboard PCB (to allow ground contact of the backplate).

  2. A backplate with a custom nut (or EMI washer, alternatively) is recommended to ensure ground connection between back plate and PCB bottom layer ground.

  3. The recommended backplate and threaded insert/custom nut dimensions are the following figure (in mm).

  4. Conductive screws without any coating/paint are recommended to secure the module to the motherboard. The screw's dimensions guidelines (in mm) are based on a recommended LPCAMM2 module-level shield.

Backplate with threaded insert or nut for ground contact to PCB
Recommended LPCAMM2 module screw dimensions

  • LPCAMM Module-level Shield

A module-level EMI shield can be installed on the LPCAMM2 module as illustrated in the pictures below. The shield must make ground contact to the ground ring on the periphery of the module. A top plate/EMI shield with conductive foam gaskets can be used to achieve the ground contact of the shield with the module PCB. The figures below show the recommended dimensions for the shield and conductive gaskets.

Optional on-module shield for LPCAMM2
Recommended dimensions for LPCAMM2 on-module shield
Critical dimensions for conductive gasket for LPCAMM2 on-module shield

  • RFI-friendly LPCAMM2 connector option

To mitigate noise radiation from the LPCAMM2 connector, an optional RFI-friendly connector has been developed with connector vendors. The connector design is comprised of a thin metal shield layer along the periphery of the connector. The shield layer may wrap around the entire connector or only along the south-edge of the connector near the differential pins. The shield layer should contact the module ground and PCB ground using compression contacts. An illustration of the connector is shown below. Customers should contact their LPCAMM2 connector vendor for part numbers and details.

RFI-friendly LPCAMM2 Connector

Intel DDR RFI Mitigation (RFIM) Software Feature

DDR RFIM is a frequency shifting RFI mitigation software feature. The DDR RFIM feature is primarily aimed at resolving narrowband RFI from memory (DDR and LPDDR technologies and both soldered-down and modules) for the Wi-Fi in high frequency bands (5 to 7GHz). By changing the DDR data rate, using Intel dynamic voltage and frequency scaling (DVFS) technology, the narrowband memory noise at the clock harmonic frequency can be shifted out of a radio band of interest, thus mitigating RFI to the radio. The change of the DDR data rate is dynamic based on the radio channel in use.

Dynamic DDR data rate selection and control can be done at the request of the Intel integrated Wi-Fi firmware (CNVi) or at the request of Intel’s DTT DDR RFIM policy. In systems with CNVi installed, the feature is enabled by default. In systems with discrete Intel or 3rd party Wi-Fi, the DDR RFIM policy must be enabled in DTT. For both cases, the OEM has the option to customize the DDR RFI table (list of Wi-Fi channels affected by each DDR frequency of the system) based on the measured platform noise.

Intel also offers a semiautomatic tool to characterize the platform DDR noise and customize the DDR RFI table that is an input to RFIM. It is highly recommended to use the tool to characterize the noise from the different memory DVFS points. Please refer to white papers #640438 and #816192 for detailed information.

DLVR RFI Mitigation

The DLVR power delivery may result in RF interference with radio bands.

The following guidelines help to reduce the RFI risk due to DLVR.

Minimize DLVR Input Planes Exposure

It is recommended that the DLVR (VCC_CORE & VCCSA ) power plane size be minimized in surface layers keeping PI requirements in consideration. Refer to power integrity requirement for resistance and VR sense feedback recommendation.

RF Decoupling Capacitors on DLVR Input Power Planes

High frequency decoupling capacitors on DLVR power plane (VCC_CORE & VCCSA) can help in DLVR noise reduction. Since there are system level dependencies for the RFI, in certain scenarios like a system with aggressive antenna placement to DLVR power plane or WWAN radio for example, it is recommended to have placeholders for decoupling capacitors. The following table and figures show the recommended values and placement for the decoupling caps and example of layout implementation.

RF Decoupling Capacitor Guideline for DLVR
Example of RF Cap Placement for DLVR power plane

Graphic (GFX) Power Planes RFI Design Guidelines

Graphics (GFX) may induce RF noise on power planes / rails that couple to radio antennas, resulting in RF interference within radio bands.

RF Decoupling Capacitors on GFX Power Planes

It is recommended to have placeholders for high-frequency decoupling capacitors on the VCCGT (GFX power plane). These decoupling capacitors may help in reducing potential GFX noise in certain scenarios such as a system with aggressive antenna placement to GFX power planes. The following table and figure show the recommended values and placement for the decoupling capacitors:

RF Decoupling Capacitor Guideline for GFX Power Planes
Case #Location of Decoupling CapacitorGFX RF Capacitors for 2.4GHz BandComments$[internal]Cap Stuffing Option for Internal Validation
Case 1Directly underneath pair of GFX power via and GND vias (Directly from BGAs) on the plane0201 size: 6 x capacitors (Suggested value: between 22pF to 33pF)Preferred placement for RF decoupling capacitors. Capacitors are recommended to be placed directly underneath the pair of GFX power via - GND vias at bottom layer or at least within the CPU’s shadow area. The value of the RF capacitor may need to be tuned with respect to the potential unintended RF power within Wi-Fi bands. Stuffed 
Case 2≤ 5mm from GFX power via BGA 0201 size: 6 x capacitors (Suggested value: between 22pF to 33pF) The value of the RF capacitor may need to be tuned with respect to the potential unintended RF power within Wi-Fi bands.Stuffed 
Case 3> 5mm away from GFX power via BGA Not recommended RF capacitors are NOT effective for RFI reduction in this location of placement.Stuffed 

HSIO RFI Mitigation

Exposed high speed I/O routing traces are regarded as RFI source. The RFI level depends on interface signal characteristics such as data rate, rise/ fall time and coupling between antenna and signal trace.

Internal Cable Selection

Shielded internal cable is recommended with two different approaches, that are:

  • Ground outer layers.

  • Outer signal routing layers with EMI shielding film (silk screening with silver/ copper ink, aluminum/ copper film lamination).

Multiple ground pins/ contacts are required to connect the internal cable to PCB ground. Figures below illustrate some guidance on internal cable in reducing cable edge emission. Shielded connector may be considered.

Internal Cable Guidance in Edge Emission Reduction

Minimize Exposed High Speed I/O Channel Routing

It is recommended that the routing of I/O interfaces in the table below be embedded in inner layers and covered by solid ground. Due to routing limitations, full stripline routing may not be possible at breakout and the routing at the connector region. Please refer to the table below for maximum microstrip length.

InterfaceData RateMax Breakout Length (Microstrip)Max Routing Length at Connector Region (Microstrip)Cable ShieldingNote

Refer to document #610694 for the latest Intel Wi-Fi module RFI/EMC recommendations.

Note: Refer to EMC Mechanical Consideration section for internal cable selection

eDP RFI Mitigation

Narrowband Spur Noise from eDP Data and TCON Clock

To prevent interference with radio bands, select the eDP data rates that ensure the fundamental frequencies and harmonics of the eDP signals do not fall into Wi-Fi radio bands. The eDP data rates 2.43 Gbps and 6.75 Gbps should be avoided to mitigate the RF noise impact on Wi-Fi radios. Other mitigation solutions such as using high-quality shielding cable for eDP and TCON connection/board or enabling spread spectrum clocking may provide effective but limited noise reduction as an alternative solution.

Mitigate eDP RF interference by preventing using data rate that falling into Wi-Fi radios
TCON clock noise falling into Wi-Fi bands

RF Interference from Embedded Display Port (eDP) Interface and TCON

In mobile designs, RF interference from eDP interface has become more problematic due to the increase of thinner and lighter devices, which limit options for effective cable shielding and antenna isolation. While the data rates increase, the high-frequency data and clocks generate RF noise that falls into Wi-Fi radio bands. Besides RF noise from eDP, timing controller (TCON), used to convert the eDP signal and drive the individual pixels of the display, could be another source of interference.

Software Mitigation Solution – Enable Intel Wi-Fi Module Notch Filter

Intel Wi-Fi module supports a notch filter enabling that is configurated through BIOS based on specific request. The notch filter solution aims for narrowband noise mitigation and may impact Wi-Fi performance in some scenarios. Please contact Intel wireless customer support for more information.

Intel Wi-Fi Module Notch Filter Implementation

On-board Shielding

In the consideration of Wi-Fi/ WWAN/ 5G antenna placement in proximity with PCB board, gaps or slits in between chassis covers allows the noise leak towards antenna. Platform noise may be guided by chassis cover towards antenna. Improved chassis design and on board shielding could isolate platform noise from interfering to the radio devices performances.

Chassis and On-board Shielding Consideration

EMI Shielding Design

An integrated active cooling and EMI shield solution implemented onto Intel LPDDR4 reference platform of Type-3 PCB is shown in the figures below. This demonstrated EMI shield covers the entire core area, including DRAM subsystem, CPU, and power delivery circuits in Type-3 PCB and is an example of the co-design of active thermal and EMI shield solutions. For key implementation principals and PCB design aspects of this shield, please refer to the Intel whitepaper # 621488, "New DRAM Technology and Compelling EMI Shield Mitigation Solutions Radio Frequency Interference (RFI) Analysis"

Reference Platform with EMI Shield Solution
EMI Gasket Surround Shield and Connect to Board Ground Pad Opening

In the using of fabric-over-foam gasket in making connection between shielding lid and frame or between shielding can and PCB, a minimum of 20% or higher compression should be considered in ensuring the electrical effectiveness. Components height and distance from shielding solution depends on heat pipe routing and system thermal & mechanical design. Shielding solution inclusive of compressed gasket should avoid physical collision and interference with components.

Gasket Compression Required for Electrical Effectiveness

EMI shielding could be one of RFI mitigation for exposed power planes and memory devices. Shielding mechanical enclosure should not have electrical openings for minimum noise leakage.

Good Conductivity Between Shielding Lid and Frame

Another example of shielding solution with co-optimized EMC-thermal solution that adopts a large metal frame interposer that cover GPU, GDDR devices, GPU voltage regulator, CPU, DDR devices and voltage regulator. The metal frame has electrical conductive interface connects to on board GND pad opening.

Example Implementation of EMC-Thermal Solution
Metal Frame Interposer with Electrical Conductive Interface to Board

Shielding cans or lids are subject to warpage issues. Shielding design should consider sufficient screws in provide effective mechanical force in the shielding mating or closure. Screw size, count and contact subject to PCB thickness, gasket interface and shielding material. Structure analysis required in ensuring the thermal/ EMI shielding provides appropriate/ uniform pressure on die, and ensuring good gasket stiffness and proper electrical contact of gasket towards PCB GND.

Adequate Mechanical Forces in Shielding Attachment

EMI/ RFI Lidless Shielding Solution

The Lidless shielding solution relies on the case (C or D cover) to be used as the lid of the fence. This design requires the use of a taller fence, electrically conductive gasket and a conductive case or conductive coated case. The conductive case can be achieved using a metallic case or a conductive coatings over a plastic chassis. The figure below shows an example implementation of this shield concept. Note: EMI Lidless shielding implementation shall include system thermal and airflow design consideration.

Example Implementation of Lidless Shielding Solution Concept

Air flow to the enclosure and mechanical strength of the shielding are factors of the shield. Balanced trade off is required for air ventilation hole for thermal conductivity and RF shielding effectiveness. An example of optimized ventilation and effective RF shielding fence is illustrated in figure below.

Trade-off between Air Flow Ventilation and RF Shielding Effectiveness

An opening in the fence allows the heat pipe to go through it, however the heat pipe must be grounded and the space between the fence and heat pipe needs to be sealed. Flexible gasket is a good option to fill the spaces, especially in complex geometries. This gasket helps to avoid rigid unions and geometry irregularities. Refer to the supplier´s data sheet to determine the requirements to achieve the electrical conductivity (percentage of compression required).The flexible gasket can be used to seal irregular components such as heat pipes or other complex geometries. When the gasket is compressed, lateral expansion can occur, which should be considered as part of the design. KOZ requirements with respect to electrical components may be needed to avoid short circuits.

Flexible Conductive Gasket for Enclosure

Shielding Ground Contact

Platform on-board shielding can be an effective mitigation options for EMC and help to reduce platform noise radiation and reduce susceptibility to external RF noise. Proper ground contact of the shield is critical to ensuring shielding effectiveness. In consideration of (λ/10) @ 7.5 GHz, the following figure shows the maximum recommended spacing between grounding pads and vias. Poor grounding contact or gaps/ seams in the shield can reduce the shielding effectiveness.

On Board Shielding Guidelines

Throughput vs. Noise

Noise from platform components such as high speed traces and clocks can radiate and couple to the antennas of integrated radios such as Wi-Fi or LTE. This is referred to as radio frequency interference and results is degraded signal to noise ratio at the input to the radio receiver. The degraded SNR will impact the data throughput as well as range on the wireless link.

Different noise sources from the platform will have different frequency spectrum. For example, a scrambled signal, such as USB3 will appear with broadband frequency content ranging from DC to 5 GHz. A clock signal, on the other hand will result in single-tone (narrow band) peaks at the harmonic frequencies of the clock frequency.

Noise Threshold Recommendation

Figure A shows measured Wi-Fi throughput as a function of RFI level (broadband and single-tone). Table A shows the noise threshold above which Wi-Fi throughput starts to decrease.

Figure B shows measured SISO reference sensitivity as a function of RFI level (broadband and narrowband noise). The 3GPP specified the SISO reference sensitivity over all LTE bands is -90.3~-93.8 dBm. Table B lists the noise threshold that the measured reference sensitivity starts to fail 3GPP requirement.

It is recommended to ensure that the platform noise coupled to the Wi-Fi/ LTE antennas be lower than this threshold.

Wi-Fi Throughput vs. RFI Level
WWAN Sensitivity vs RFI

VCCPRIM_VNNAON_(Type-3_PCB)

Settings

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1Route VCCPRIM_VNNAON on at least 3 power layers (30 um copper thickness each) from VRM to processor BGA & ensure adjacent ground layers available for return pathVCCPRIM_VNNAON_1
2Short VCPRIM_VNNAON BGA with power plane on 2 layers with 30um copper thickness eachVCCPRIM_VNNAON_2
3VCCPRIM_VNNAON VRM uses pseudo differential sensing. The power & ground sense lines are connected to CN8 & CN9 BGA respectivelyVCCPRIM_VNNAON_3
4Short VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR BGA CT18, CV18, CT16 & CV16 with a power planeVCCPRIM_VNNAON_4
5Merge VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR to VCCPRIM_VNNAON power plane within 1mm from package edge through an LC filter placed <1mm from package edge with the following inductor requirements: ► Inductance range : 0.47-1 uH ► Max DCR rating: 55mΩ Refer image for design implementation guidanceVCCPRIM_VNNAON_5
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_1
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_2
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_3
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_4
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_5
Notes
Note
Place VRM bulk cap or additional MLCC caps to keep sense voltage below threshold limit & to fulfill PD requirements
Heighten capacitor effectiveness by placing them from VRM to package in the following order : 0402 → 0603 → 0805 →Bulk
Establish robust return path for decoupling capacitor by minimizing the distance between power & ground via pairs as well as placing the via pairs as close as possible to the capacitor pads
Align capacitor pads to the current path flowing from VR to package
Customers can choose capacitors of any form factor if the capacitors meet the recommended parasitic capacitance.
Component PlacementForm FactorValueQuantityNoteReference Design
Primary Side060322 uF4Place 4 x 0603 22uF with distance <10mm from Package edge. VCCPRIM_VNNAON_6
Secondary side060322 uF2Place 2 x 0603 22uF cap under VCCPRIM_VNNAON BGAs.VCCPRIM_VNNAON_7
Secondary Side040210uF4Place 4 x 0402 10uF caps under VCCPRIM_VNNAON BGAs. VCCPRIM_VNNAON_7
Secondary Side0603/040222uF1Pair 0603/0402 22uF cap with inductor to form LC-filterVCCPRIM_VNNAON_7
Secondary Side06030.47 uH / 55mΩ DCR1Merge VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR to VCCPRIM_VNNAON power plane within 1mm from package edge through an LC filter placed <1mm from package edge with the following inductor requirements: ► Inductance range : 0.47-1 uH ► Max DCR rating: 55mΩVCCPRIM_VNNAON_7
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_6
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_7

Settings (Internal)

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1Route VCCPRIM_VNNAON on at least 3 power layers (30 um copper thickness each) from VRM to processor BGA & ensure adjacent ground layers available for return pathVCCPRIM_VNNAON_1
2Short VCPRIM_VNNAON BGA with power plane on 2 layers with 30um copper thickness eachVCCPRIM_VNNAON_2
3VCCPRIM_VNNAON VRM uses pseudo differential sensing. The power & ground sense lines are connected to CN8 & CN9 BGA respectivelyVCCPRIM_VNNAON_3
4Short VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR BGA CT18, CV18, CT16 & CV16 with a power planeVCCPRIM_VNNAON_4
5Merge VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR to VCCPRIM_VNNAON power plane within 1mm from package edge through an LC filter placed <1mm from package edge with the following inductor requirements: ► Inductance range : 0.47-1 uH ► Max DCR rating: 55mΩ Refer image for design implementation guidanceVCCPRIM_VNNAON_5
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_1
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_2
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_3
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_4
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_5
Notes
Note
Place VRM bulk cap or additional MLCC caps to keep sense voltage below threshold limit & to fulfill PD requirements
Heighten capacitor effectiveness by placing them from Processor to VR in the following order : 0402 → 0603 → 0805 →Bulk
Establish robust return path for decoupling capacitor by minimizing the distance between power & ground via pairs as well as placing the via pairs as close as possible to the capacitor pads
Customers can choose capacitors of any form factor if the capacitors meet the recommended parasitic capacitance.
Component PlacementForm FactorValueSoldered DownISC SocketPPV SocketNoteReference Design
Primary Side060322 uF444Place 4 x 0603 22uF with distance <10mm from Package edge. VCCPRIM_VNNAON_6
Secondary side060322 uF222Place 2 x 0603 22uF cap under VCCPRIM_VNNAON BGAs.VCCPRIM_VNNAON_7
Secondary Side040210uF444Place 4 x 0402 10uF caps under VCCPRIM_VNNAON BGAs. VCCPRIM_VNNAON_7
Secondary Side0603/040222uF111Pair 0603/0402 22uF cap with inductor to form LC-filterVCCPRIM_VNNAON_7
Secondary Side06030.47 uH / 55mΩ DCR111Merge VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR to VCCPRIM_VNNAON power plane within 10mm from package edge through an LC filter placed <1mm from package edge with the following inductor requirements: ► Inductance range : 0.47-1 uH ► Max DCR rating: 55mΩVCCPRIM_VNNAON_7
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_6
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_7

VCCPRIM_VNNAON_(Type-4_PCB)

Settings

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1Route VCCPRIM_VNNAON on at least 2 power layers (30 um copper thickness each) with wide plane from VRM to processor BGA & ensure adjacent ground layers available for return pathVCCPRIM_VNNAON_1
2Short VCPRIM_VNNAON BGA with power plane on 2 layers with 30um copper thickness eachVCCPRIM_VNNAON_2
3VCCPRIM_VNNAON VRM uses pseudo differential sensing. The power & ground sense lines are connected to CN8 & CN9 BGA respectivelyVCCPRIM_VNNAON_3
4Short VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR BGA CT18, CV18, CT16 & CV16 with a power planeVCCPRIM_VNNAON_4
5Merge VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR to VCCPRIM_VNNAON power plane within 1mm from package edge through an LC filter placed <1mm from package edge with the following inductor requirements: ► Inductance range : 0.47-1 uH ► Max DCR rating: 55mΩ Refer image for design implementation guidanceVCCPRIM_VNNAON_5
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_1
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_2
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_3
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_4
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_5
Notes
Note
Place VRM bulk cap or additional MLCC caps to keep sense voltage below threshold limit & to fulfill PD requirements
Heighten capacitor effectiveness by placing them from VRM to package in the following order : 0402 → 0603 → 0805 →Bulk
Establish robust return path for decoupling capacitor by minimizing the distance between power & ground via pairs as well as placing the via pairs as close as possible to the capacitor pads
Align capacitor pads to the current path flowing from VR to package
Customers can choose capacitors of any form factor if the capacitors meet the recommended parasitic capacitance.
Component PlacementForm FactorValueQuantityNoteReference Design
Primary Side060322 uF4Place 4 x 0603 22uF with distance <10mm from Package edge. VCCPRIM_VNNAON_6
Secondary side060322 uF2Place 2 x 0603 22uF cap under VCCPRIM_VNNAON BGAs.VCCPRIM_VNNAON_7
Secondary Side040210uF4Place 4 x 0402 10uF caps under VCCPRIM_VNNAON BGAs. VCCPRIM_VNNAON_7
Secondary Side0603/040222uF1Pair 0603/0402 22uF cap with inductor to form LC-filterVCCPRIM_VNNAON_7
Secondary Side06030.47 uH / 55mΩ DCR1Merge VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR to VCCPRIM_VNNAON power plane within 1mm from package edge through an LC filter placed <1mm from package edge with the following inductor requirements: ► Inductance range : 0.47-1 uH ► Max DCR rating: 55mΩVCCPRIM_VNNAON_7

VCCPRIM_IO(Type-3 PCB)

Settings

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1VCCPRIM_IO VRM uses pseudo differential sensing. The power sense line is connected to VCCPRIM_IO_SENSE BGA, and the VSS_VCCPRIM_IO_SENSE line is connected to VSS_VCCPRIM_IO_SENSE BGA (DF9) adjacent to VCCPRIM_IO_SENSE BGA (DF8)VCCPRIM_IO_1
2Route VCCPRIM_IO power plane from VR output inductor to the BGA on Layer 1, Layer 6 and Layer 8. Adjacent layer from VCCPRIM_IO power plane should be ground.VCCPRIM_IO_2
3VCCPRIM_IO_FLTR should be merged with VCCPRIM_IO after LC filter on Layer 8VCCPRIM_IO_2
4Route VCCPRIM_IO_FLTR_CAP from BGA directly down to the capacitor component on bottom layer
VCCPRIM_IO_1
VCCPRIM_IO_2
Notes
Note
Customers can choose capacitors of any form factor if the capacitors meet the recommended parasitic capacitance.
Component PlacementForm FactorValueQuantityNoteReference Design
Secondary side 040210 uF4Place right below the VCCPRIM_IO BGA VCCPRIM_IO_4,VCCPRIM_IO_5
Secondary side060322 uF1Place right below the VCCPRIM_IO BGA VCCPRIM_IO_4,VCCPRIM_IO_5
Secondary side (Inductor)06031 uH/350mOhm1Inductor component of the LC filter from VCCPRIM_IO_FLTR railVCCPRIM_IO_4,VCCPRIM_IO_5
Secondary side040210 uF1Decoupling capacitor placed on VCCPRIM_IO_FLTR rail for LC filtering purposeVCCPRIM_IO_4,VCCPRIM_IO_5
Secondary side0402/0201Placeholder1Place right below the VCCPRIM_IO_FLTR_CAP BGAVCCPRIM_IO_4,VCCPRIM_IO_5
VCCPRIM_IO_4
VCCPRIM_IO_5

VCCPRIM_IO(Type-4 PCB)

Settings

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1VCCPRIM_IO VRM uses pseudo differential sensing. The power sense line is connected to VCCPRIM_IO_SENSE BGA, and the VSS_VCCPRIM_IO_SENSE line is connected to VSS_VCCPRIM_IO_SENSE BGA (DF9) adjacent to VCCPRIM_IO_SENSE BGA (DF8)VCCPRIM_IO_1
2Route VCCPRIM_IO power plane from VR output inductor to the BGA on primary side. Other layer should be ground.VCCPRIM_IO_2
3VCCPRIM_IO_FLTR should be merged with VCCPRIM_IO after LC filter on secondary side VCCPRIM_IO_2
4Route VCCPRIM_IO_FLTR_CAP from BGA directly down to the capacitor component on bottom layer

VCCPRIM_1P8

Settings

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1Route the VCCPRIM_1P8, VCCPRIM_1P8_FLTRA and VCCPRIM_1P8_FLTRB on Layer 4, with immediate ground reference. VCCPRIM_1P8_FLTRA should be merged with VCCPRIM_1P8 after LC filter on Layer 1. VCCPRIM_1P8_FLTRB can be merged with VCCPRIM_1P8 on Layer 4.VCCPRIM_1P8_1
VCCPRIM_1P8_1
Notes
Note
Power and ground via pairs should be placed close to capacitor pads to provide proper vertical connections when placing capacitor on the secondary side.
Customers can choose capacitors of any form factor if the capacitors meet the recommended parasitic capacitance.
Component PlacementForm FactorValueQuantityNoteReference Design
Primary side (Inductor)0805 / 06031uH1Inductor component of the LC filter from VCCPRIM_1P8 rail to VCCPRIM_1P8_FLTRA rail. It must meet electrical requirements: max DCR < 100mOhm and rated current >200 mA.VCCPRIM_1P8_2, VCCPRIM_1P8_3, VCCPRIM_1P8_4
Primary side060322uF2Decoupling capacitor placed on VCCPRIM_1P8_FLTRA rail for LC filtering purpose.VCCPRIM_1P8_2, VCCPRIM_1P8_3, VCCPRIM_1P8_4
Secondary side02011uF1Place under VCCPRIM_1P8_FLTRA BGAs.VCCPRIM_1P8_2, VCCPRIM_1P8_3
Secondary side0603Placeholder1Place under VCCPRIM_1P8_FLTRB BGAs. VCCPRIM_1P8_2, VCCPRIM_1P8_3
Secondary side02011uF1Place under VCCPRIM_1P8_FLTRB BGAs.VCCPRIM_1P8_2, VCCPRIM_1P8_3
Secondary side0402 / 0201Placeholder1Place under VCCPRIM_1P8 BGAsVCCPRIM_1P8_2, VCCPRIM_1P8_3
VCCPRIM_1P8_2
VCCPRIM_1P8_3

VCCGT(H404/T3/0.8mm PCB)

Settings

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1Design solid planes for a continuous current flow path from VR output to BGA. Please see reference image as an example of feasible placement. VCCGT_H404_T3_0.8mm_1
2Adjacent solid ground to power planes for good return path.
3Sense pins routed as differential pair to VR. Avoid routing adjacent to noisy power plane and have adjacent solid ground plane for good return path.
VCCGT_H404_T3_0.8mm_1
Notes
Note
1. Smaller capacitors should be placed closest to the package. For example: Package -> 0201 -> 0402 ->0603 ->Bulk -> VR.
2. For bottom layer capacitor placement, place 0201, 0402, 0603 capacitors directly under the package and cannot be placed at the edge.
3. Capacitor recommendation based on VR solution with 150 kHz VR bandwidth or 600 kHz switching frequency, assuming BW=1/4 of Fsw.
4. Align capacitor pads along current flow path from VR to package. Make sure decoupling capacitors have power/ ground via pairs connected as close as possible to the capacitors pads.
5. Use MLCC components with 6.3 V voltage rating.
6. Please refer to acoustic noise mitigation technical advisory document #575216 for more details.
Component PlacementForm FactorValueQuantityNoteReference Design
Primary side7343330 uF2Recommended capacitor ESR = 4.5mOhm with 2.5V voltage rating.VCCGT_H404_T3_0.8mm_2
Secondary side040210 uF11VCCGT_H404_T3_0.8mm_3
Secondary side060322uF7VCCGT_H404_T3_0.8mm_3
Secondary side0603Placeholder9VCCGT_H404_T3_0.8mm_3
VCCGT_H404_T3_0.8mm_2
VCCGT_H404_T3_0.8mm_3

Settings (Internal)

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1Design solid planes for a continuous current flow path from VR output to BGA. Please see reference image as an example of feasible placement. VCCGT_T3_ERB_1
2Adjacent solid ground to power planes for good return path.
3Sense pins routed as differential pair to VR. Avoid routing adjacent to noisy power plane and have adjacent solid ground plane for good return path.
VCCGT_T3_ERB_1
Notes
Note
1. Smaller capacitors should be placed closest to the package. For example: Package -> 0201 -> 0402 ->0603 ->Bulk -> VR.
2. Capacitor recommendation based on VR solution with 150 kHz VR bandwidth or 600 kHz switching frequency, assuming BW=1/4 of Fsw.
3. Align capacitor pads along current flow path from VR to package. Make sure decoupling capacitors have power/ ground via pairs connected as close as possible to the capacitors pads.
4. Use MLCC components with 6.3 V voltage rating.
5. Please refer to acoustic noise mitigation technical advisory document #575216 for more details.
Component PlacementForm FactorValueSoldered DownISC SocketPPV SocketNoteReference Design
Primary side7343330 uF222Recommended capacitor ESR = 4.5mOhm with 2.5V voltage rating.VCCGT_T3_ERB_2
Primary side7343Placeholder111These are the compensation caps for the socket.VCCGT_T3_ERB_2
Secondary side02012.2uF133
Secondary side040210 uF111111VCCGT_T3_ERB_3
Secondary side060322 uF577VCCGT_T3_ERB_3
Secondary side0201Placeholder200These are the compensation caps for the socket.VCCGT_T3_ERB_3
Secondary side0402Placeholder101010VCCGT_T3_ERB_3
Secondary side0603Placeholder211919VCCGT_T3_ERB_3
VCCGT_T3_ERB_2
VCCGT_T3_ERB_3

VCCGT(H12Xe/T3/0.9mm PCB)

Settings

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1Design solid planes for a continuous current flow path from VR output to BGA. Please see reference image as an example of feasible placement. VCCGT_H12Xe_T3_0.9mm_1
2Adjacent solid ground to power planes for good return path.
3Sense pins routed as differential pair to VR. Avoid routing adjacent to noisy power plane and have adjacent solid ground plane for good return path.
VCCGT_H12Xe_T3_0.9mm_1
Notes
Note
1. Smaller capacitors should be placed closest to the package. For example: Package -> 0201 -> 0402 ->0603 ->Bulk -> VR.
2. For bottom layer capacitor placement, place 0201, 0402, 0603 capacitors directly under the package and cannot be placed at the edge.
3. Capacitor recommendation based on VR solution with 150 kHz VR bandwidth or 600 kHz switching frequency, assuming BW=1/4 of Fsw.
4. Align capacitor pads along current flow path from VR to package. Make sure decoupling capacitors have power/ ground via pairs connected as close as possible to the capacitors pads.
5. Use MLCC components with 6.3 V voltage rating.
6. Please refer to acoustic noise mitigation technical advisory document #575216 for more details.
Component PlacementForm FactorValueQuantityNoteReference Design
Primary side7343330 uF2Recommended capacitor ESR = 4.5 mOhm with 2.5V voltage rating.VCCGT_H12Xe_T3_0.9mm_2
Secondary side040210 uF11VCCGT_H12Xe_T3_0.9mm_3
Secondary side060322uF7VCCGT_H12Xe_T3_0.9mm_3
Secondary side0603Placeholder9VCCGT_H12Xe_T3_0.9mm_3
VCCGT_H12Xe_T3_0.9mm_2
VCCGT_H12Xe_T3_0.9mm_3

VCCGT(H12Xe/T4/0.8mm PCB)

Settings

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1Design solid planes for a continuous current flow path from VR output to BGA. Please see reference image as an example of feasible placement. VCCGT_H12Xe_T4_0.8mm_1
2Adjacent solid ground to power planes for good return path.
3Sense pins routed as differential pair to VR. Avoid routing adjacent to noisy power plane and have adjacent solid ground plane for good return path.
VCCGT_H12Xe_T4_0.8mm_1
Notes
Note
1. Smaller capacitors should be placed closest to the package. For example: Package -> 0201 -> 0402 ->0603 ->Bulk -> VR.
2. For bottom layer capacitor placement, place 0201, 0402, 0603 capacitors directly under the package and cannot be placed at the edge.
3. Capacitor recommendation based on VR solution with 150 kHz VR bandwidth or 600 kHz switching frequency, assuming BW=1/4 of Fsw.
4. Align capacitor pads along current flow path from VR to package. Make sure decoupling capacitors have power/ ground via pairs connected as close as possible to the capacitors pads.
5. Use MLCC components with 6.3 V voltage rating.
6. Please refer to acoustic noise mitigation technical advisory document #575216 for more details.
Component PlacementForm FactorValueQuantityNoteReference Design
Primary side7343330 uF2Recommended capacitor ESR = 4.5mOhm with 2.5V voltage rating.VCCGT_H12Xe_T4_0.8mm_2
Secondary side040210 uF11VCCGT_H12Xe_T4_0.8mm_3
Secondary side060322uF7VCCGT_H12Xe_T4_0.8mm_3
Secondary side0603Placeholder9VCCGT_H12Xe_T4_0.8mm_3
VCCGT_H12Xe_T4_0.8mm_2
VCCGT_H12Xe_T4_0.8mm_3

VCC_LP_ECORE(H12Xe/T4/0.8mm PCB)

Settings

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1Design solid planes for a continuous current flow path from VR output to BGA. Please see reference image as an example of feasible placement. VCC_LP_ECORE_H12Xe_T4_0.8mm_1
2Adjacent solid ground to power planes for good return path.
3Sense pins routed as differential pair to VR. Avoid routing adjacent to noisy power plane and have adjacent solid ground plane for good return path.
VCC_LP_ECORE_H12Xe_T4_0.8mm_1
Notes
Note
1. Smaller capacitors should be placed closest to the package. For example: Package -> 0201 -> 0402 ->0603 ->Bulk -> VR.
2. For bottom layer capacitor placement, place 0201, 0402, 0603 capacitors directly under the package and cannot be placed at the edge.
3. Capacitor recommendation based on VR solution with 150 kHz VR bandwidth or 600 kHz switching frequency, assuming BW=1/4 of Fsw.
4. Align capacitor pads along current flow path from VR to package. Make sure decoupling capacitors have power/ ground via pairs connected as close as possible to the capacitors pads.
5. Use MLCC components with 6.3 V voltage rating.
6. Please refer to acoustic noise mitigation technical advisory document #575216 for more details.
Component PlacementForm FactorValueQuantityNoteReference Design
Primary side060322uF6VCC_LP_ECORE_H12Xe_T4_0.8mm_2
Primary side7343330uF1Recommended capacitor ESR = 4.5mOhm with 2.5V voltage rating.VCC_LP_ECORE_H12Xe_T4_0.8mm_2
Secondary side040210uF4Place beneath BGAVCC_LP_ECORE_H12Xe_T4_0.8mm_3
Secondary side060322uF4Place beneath BGAVCC_LP_ECORE_H12Xe_T4_0.8mm_3
Secondary side0603Placeholder1VCC_LP_ECORE_H12Xe_T4_0.8mm_3
VCC_LP_ECORE_H12Xe_T4_0.8mm_2
VCC_LP_ECORE_H12Xe_T4_0.8mm_3

VCC_LP_ECORE(H484/T3/0.9mm PCB)

Settings

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1Design solid planes for a continuous current flow path from VR output to BGA. Please see reference image as an example of feasible placement. VCC_LP_ECORE_H484_T3_0.9mm_1
2Adjacent solid ground to power planes for good return path.
3Sense pins routed as differential pair to VR. Avoid routing adjacent to noisy power plane and have adjacent solid ground plane for good return path.
VCC_LP_ECORE_H484_T3_0.9mm_1
Notes
Note
1. Smaller capacitors should be placed closest to the package. For example: Package -> 0201 -> 0402 ->0603 ->Bulk -> VR.
2. For bottom layer capacitor placement, place 0201, 0402, 0603 capacitors directly under the package and cannot be placed at the edge.
3. Capacitor recommendation based on VR solution with 150 kHz VR bandwidth or 600 kHz switching frequency, assuming BW=1/4 of Fsw.
4. Align capacitor pads along current flow path from VR to package. Make sure decoupling capacitors have power/ ground via pairs connected as close as possible to the capacitors pads.
5. Use MLCC components with 6.3 V voltage rating.
6. Please refer to acoustic noise mitigation technical advisory document #575216 for more details.

VDDQ_1

DDR5 Device Decoupling

Memory Down Decoupling Config: X16 SDP

Description: This is PI guidance for the DDR5 x16 SDP memory down solution if the customers choose to merge VDD/ VDDQ rails on the platform.

The capacitor quantity if for 8 DRAM devices. Each DDR channel to have two X16 DRAM devices. The layout example shows the decoupling cap placement for 4 DRAM devices. The same strategy can be extended to all the 8 X16 DRAM devices. Customers should check the DRAM supplier datasheets for the VDD/ VDDQ voltage levels and only merge if they are the same voltage.

Notes
Note
Information provided here is only for guidance. Customers are responsible for meeting all JEDEC SPECS on the Memory power rails
Voltage RailCapacitor Form Factor and ValueQuantityNotesReference Design
VDD/VDDQ (VDD & VDDQ rails are merged on the platform)0402/ 0201, 1uF324 caps per DRAM, as close as possible to VDD/ VDDQ BGAs. Customers may adjust the capacitor quantity/ form factor/ value to meet the JEDEC spec.DDR5 Memory Down X16
VDD/ VDDQ (VDD & VDDQ rails are merged on the platform)0402, 10 uF81 cap per DRAM, as close as possible to VDD/ VDDQ BGAs. Customers may adjust the capacitor quantity/ form factor/ value to meet the JEDEC spec.DDR5 Memory Down X16
VPP0402/ 0201, 1 uF162 caps per DRAM. One per short side connecting the VPP BGAs. Customers may adjust the capacitor quantity/ form factor/ value to meet the JEDEC spec.DDR5 Memory Down X16
VPP0402, 10 uF81 cap per DRAM, close as possible to VPP BGAs. Customers may adjust the capacitor quantity/ form factor/ value to meet the JEDEC spec.DDR5 Memory Down X16
DDR5 Memory Down X16

Small Outline Dual In-line Memory Module (SODIMM)

DDR5 SODIMM comes with PMIC/ VR and decoupling on the module card itself, hence no additional decoupling guidelines are required. Nevertheless the source supply to the DDR5 SODIMM needs to follow the JEDEC/ vendor specification sheet.

DDR5 SODIMM comes with PMIC/ VR and decoupling on the module card itself, hence no additional decoupling guidelines are required. Nevertheless the source supply to the DDR5 SODIMM needs to follow the JEDEC/ vendor specification sheet.

LPCAMM2 E1

LPCAMM2 E1 module

Description: LPCAMM2 E1 module has a configurable VDDQ rail option i.e. VDDQ rail can be sourced from on module PMIC or from the Motherboard VRM. This section provides routing recommendations for using Motherboard VDDQ VRM shared with the SOC on 8 Layer and 10 Layer Type-3 Motherboard stackup.

A shared VDDQ rail between the SOC and LPCAMM2 E1 module is required to support speeds above 7467 MT/s.

Notes
Note
Information provided here is only for guidance. Customers are responsible for meeting all LPCAMM2 E1 connector JEDEC SPECS.
VSS referencing is recommended for the VDDQ power rail.
Voltage RailCapacitor Form Factor and ValueQuantityNotesReference Design
VDDQ0603, 47 uf2Customers may adjust the capacitor quantity/ form factor/ value to meet the JEDEC spec.LPCAMM2_E1_10L, LPCAMM2_E1_8L
LPCAMM2_E1_10L
LPCAMM2_E1_8L

LPDDR5/x Device Decoupling

Memory Down Decoupling Config: 4X32

Description: LPDDR5x x32 memory down PI solution guidance with eDVFSC enabled on the platform.

eDVFSC is an optional power savings feature for LP5x speed ≤3200 MT/s. eDVFSC requires an independent VDD2L rail on the platform. If the eDVFSC support is not desired on the platform, customers can merge DRAM VDD2L ball with the VDD2H rail. Customers should consult the DRAM vendors for Z(f) spec guidance for merged VDD2H/VDD2L rail.

Notes
Note
TYPE-4 (2-x-2+) DRAM power rail layer assignment is provided in LPDDR5x_TYPE4_1
TYPE-3 10L DRAM power rail layer assignment is provided in LPDDR5x_TYPE3_1
VSS referencing is recommended for all the Memory power rails
Information provided here is only for guidance. Customers are responsible for meeting all JEDEC SPECS on the Memory power rails
Voltage RailCapacitor Form Factor and ValueQuantityNotesReference Design
VDD2H0201, 1 uF164 caps per DRAM, 1 per side close to VDD2H BGAs. Customers may adjust the capacitor quantity/ form factor/ value to meet the JEDEC spec.LPDDR5x_TYPE4_2, LPDDR5x_TYPE3_2
VDD2H0402, 10 uF41 cap per DRAM. Customers may adjust the capacitor quantity/ form factor/ value to meet the JEDEC spec.LPDDR5x_TYPE4_2, LPDDR5x_TYPE3_2
VDDQ0201, 1 uF164 caps per DRAM, 1 per each corner close to VDDQ BGAs. Customers may adjust the capacitor quantity/ form factor/ value to meet the JEDEC spec.LPDDR5x_TYPE4_3, LPDDR5x_TYPE3_3
VDDQ0402, 10 uF41 cap per DRAM. Customers may adjust the capacitor quantity/ form factor/ value to meet the JEDEC spec.LPDDR5x_TYPE4_3, LPDDR5x_TYPE3_3
VDD10201, 1 uF164 caps per DRAM, 1 per each VDD1 BGA. Customers may adjust the capacitor quantity/ form factor/ value to meet the JEDEC spec.LPDDR5x_TYPE4_4, LPDDR5x_TYPE3_4
VDD10402, 10 uF41 cap per DRAM. Customers may adjust the capacitor quantity/ form factor/ value to meet the JEDEC spec.LPDDR5x_TYPE4_4, LPDDR5x_TYPE3_4
VDD2L0201, 1uF164 cap per DRAM, 1 per each corner close to VDD2L BGA's Customers may adjust the capacitor quantity/ form factor/ value to meet the JEDEC spec.LPDDR5x_TYPE4_5, LPDDR5x_TYPE3_5
VDD2L0402, 10uF41 cap per DRAM. Customers may adjust the capacitor quantity/ form factor/ value to meet the JEDEC spec.LPDDR5x_TYPE4_5, LPDDR5x_TYPE3_5
LPDDR5x_TYPE4_1
LPDDR5x_TYPE4_2
LPDDR5x_TYPE4_3
LPDDR5x_TYPE4_4
LPDDR5x_TYPE4_5
LPDDR5x_TYPE3_1
LPDDR5x_TYPE3_2
LPDDR5x_TYPE3_3
LPDDR5x_TYPE3_4
LPDDR5x_TYPE3_5
